userreviews.userReview:
The third volume of Fantographics complete reprinting of Peanuts is just as gorgeous, but because of the repetition of some gags and punchlines (both within this book and from the older volumes) I feel obligated to knock a star off. The strips are still funny, the beauty of it is that these gags were just as funny 40 years of repeats later, but they're also the reason the strip got a stale reputation in the first place. But I can't hold that against Schulz, he couldn't possibly have guessed how popular his strip was going to become (in 1955 the circulation was still small) and ever be collected even. If you're writing a new strip every day you're going to reuse a joke or three.Snoopy still gets around for the most part on four paws, but he really begins to take off as something more than canine in this volume. His impressions of animals, famous personages, and neighborhood children take off, much to consternation of Charlie Brown. By this time Snoopy is definitely Charlie Brown's dog, too, whereas before he had been a true "neighborhood dog" or possibly even Shermy's.The timelessness of Peanuts is a part of its charm but every once and awhile Schulz couldn't resist commenting on the emerging pop culture of the kid's, whether it was devotion for Miss Frances from a tv show called "Ding Dong School" or Davey Crocket. Schulz is best when he walks that line between "adult" awareness and conventions, and the simple dimensions of childhood thinking. 
This is the last volume I have on hand, and only because I bought it for my dad a few Christmases ago, his birth year, but I will be keeping an eye out for later volumes. There is some repetition, but plenty of genuine insight. Still, it's probably best I'm taking a break from them for awhile. GoComics has every Peanuts strip, including reprints, up on their site but several aren't available by their original publication dates so some gems, like Charlie Brown's first tree'd kite, Linus' exposure to literary criticism from Lucy, and a great moral relativism lesson from Lucy and Linus, among others, can't appear today. But that left room for this:More than enough reason to continue on.Finally, I got a suprise treat in this volume. One of our "inherited" toys from older cousins was a Viewmaster and dozens of slide sets. You remember Viewmasters don't you? The paper disks you slid into the plastic goggles, the 3D images that changed with a satisfying click-shunk of a lever. One set we had was of Peanuts and this exact Sunday strip was one of them!

The cast: Charlie Brown, Lucy van Pelt, Linus van Pelt, Snoopy, Schroeder, Violet, Patty, Shermy, and Pig-Pen. Charlotte Braun only lasts a few strips into this volume, and then she disappears forever. I find it interesting that the cover of this volume is dedicated to Pig-Pen, because he wasn't actually in it that much. I guess there's only so many times Schulz could make a joke about a kid who hates baths.By now, 5 years into the birth of the most beloved comic of all time, PEANUTS, the main cast of characters, for the most part, have found their identities. Charlie Brown is the depressed, paranoid blockhead that the world now loves. Lucy is the demanding, loud fussbudget that likes to make up "little known facts." Linus, while still not a philosopher yet, has found his security blanket, and Schroeder his piano. Snoopy, on the other hand, needs a little more time. When PEANUTS first started, Charlie Brown was the character Schulz identified most with (Charlie=Charles); but somewhere along the line, around 10 years in, I think, Schulz found much more in common with the most famous dog in the world (I SAID IT, GOOFY!), Snoopy. And while I'm only half-way there with this volume, it's delightful to see Snoopy slowly grow in both personality and in how Schulz draws him. He's still more puppy than human right now, but Schulz has finally settled on using thought bubbles for Snoopy, and he's started trying to be anything but a dog: a rhino, alligator, snake, etc.One last thing: The introduction to this volume was written by Matt Groening, the creator of the Simpsons. I never knew how much PEANUTS inspired him as an artist, but it was such a brilliant intro.Can't wait to finish up the '50s!

снупі переживає серйозну кризу самоідентифікації;лайнус знає, що щастя – у фланелевому пледі, і відстоює його перед загрозами ззовні;люсі все ще не втрачає надії вийти заміж за шродера;шродер, утім, не зраджує своїй любові – класичній музиці; вайолет влаштовує вечірки, на які цілеспрямовано не запрошує чарлі брауна;а бідолашний чарлі браун намагається зрозуміти, чому його ніхто не любить. і так щодня, з неділями включно.

Snoopy's Snoopy, we get the first football kick, the tree eats kites, etc. Schulz is finding the iconic elements of the strip, though there are still occasional odd elements (Snoopy actually talks once or twice, we hear an adult's voice once). Many, many hilarious strips; one forgets how good Schulz was at sight gags.

Snoopy starts to pretend; Linus learns how to walk and gets his security blanket; Lucy pulls the ball out from Charlie Brown for what appears to be the first time. It all begins here. I find it fun reading where things I am familiar with growing up happened for the first time. If you enjoy Peanuts, you'll enjoy this book.

I mean, come on, who does it better? Early Schulz strips have a pleasant simplicity. Panels lean on quiet--there's a lot of room to breath. This early on, Linus is a baby prodigy, and his savant gags are a real highlight of this volume.
The best.

In this Peanuts volume, Snoopy continues to evolve his knack for impressions of animals (and Violet), revealing the true genius of simplicity that is is Charles Schulz' work; what can't you do with a pair of black ears?Linus continues to display his amazing superiority in air sketching and snow sculpting, and as usual seeks comfort from his ever-present blanket, but at times adopts the refreshing c'est-la-vie attitude "in 500 years, who'll know the difference?".One of my perhaps favorite things in Peanuts is when Lucy teaches her brother "little known facts" about the world; information so wrong it makes Charlie Brown burst into choruses of "good grief!", makes his stomac hurt and eventually we see him banging his head against trees. Many good examples of Lucy's charming lectures are included in the song Little Known Facts from the musical You're A Good Man, Charlie Brown:LUCYDo you see that tree?it is a Fir tree.It's called a Fir tree because it gives us fur,For coats,It also gives us wool in the wintertime.LINUSI never knew that before, Lucy. That's very interesting.LUCYThis is an elm tree.It's very little.But it will grow up into a giant tree,An oak.You can tell how old it is by counting it's leaves.LINUSGosh, Lucy, that's fascinating.CHARLIE BROWNNow wait a minute, Lucy. I don't mean to interfere, but-LUCYAnd way up there,Those fluffy little white things,Those are clouds,They make the wind blow.And way down there,Those tiny little black things,Those are bugs,They make the grass grow.LINUSIs that so?LUCYThat's right. They run around all day long, tugging andtugging at each tiny seedling until it grows into a greattall blade of grass.LINUSBoy, that's interesting.CHARLIE BROWNOh, good grief.LUCYAnd this thing here.It's called a hydrant.They grow all over,And no one seems to knowJust howA little thing like thatGives so much water.D'you see that bird?It's called an Eagle,But since it's little it has another name,A Sparrow,And on Christmas and ThanksgivingWe eat them.CHARLIE BROWNLucy, how can you say that?! I'm sorry, but I can't standidly by and listen to-LUCYAnd way up there,The little stars and planets,Make the rain,That falls in showers.And when it's cold and winter is upon us,The snow comes up,Just like the flowers.CHARLIE BROWNNow, Lucy, I know that's wrong. Snow doesn't come up,it comes down.LUCYAfter it comes up, the wind blows it around so itlooks like it's coming down but actually it comes upout of the ground- like grass. It comes up, Charlie Brown,snow comes up!CHARLIE BROWNOh, good grief!LINUSLucy, why is Charlie Brown banging his head againstthat tree?LUCYTo loosen the bark to make the tree grow faster.Clouds can make the wind blowBugs can make the grass growSo, there you goThese are little known factsThat nowYou know!Leading man Charlie Brown is as insecure as ever, and has plenty of football, baseball and kite-related faliures in this volume as well. Like always, he also struggles to make people like him, and once, talking to Violet, he realizes that maybe the reason people don't like him is because he's always whining about people not liking him.This volume is adorned by the ever filthy Pig-Pen however, whose dirtiness is limitless (we once spot an apparently unknown clean character though, who by the end of the strip is back to his old grimy self).This volume of the Complete Peanuts is as wonderful as ever, bringing many smiles and giggles and calming effects before sleep.This book also has an enthusiastic foreword by Matt Groening of The Simpsons.

These early Peanuts strips are really interesting for the differences from the later strips:1. Some of the major characters (Violet, Patty--not Peppermint Patty but another character named Patty--and Shermy) in these strips have almost completely disappeared by the 1970s.2. Schultz draws Snoopy and Lucy slightly differently in these early strips--there is a real, noticeable difference.3. Snoopy actually seems to talk in many of these strips: Schutlz doesn't use the thought bubbles but the direct dialogue bubbles that all the human characters use.4. We actually hear (thought we don't see) the voices of an adult, Linus and Lucy's mother, in several strips.5. There are a whole range of characters that Schultz has not yet introduced: Charlie Brown's little sister Sally, Peppermint Patty, Marcie, Woodstock, and Rerun, to name a few.6. Lucy is not quite so hostile and mean, but she certainly shows the early signs of the little girl she will become. In many ways, she is rather naive and innocent in these early strips.7. One of my favorite strips in this collection (September 12, 1956) shows Charlie Brown actually successfully kicking the football, but it is Schroeder who is holding the football and not Lucy.Also interesting about this edition of collected strips is that the introduction was written by Matt Groening, the creator of the Simpsons. Groening cites Schultz as a major influence and praises him effusively. I find it amazing and delightful at the wide range of people of all types who have been influenced by Peanuts, which is, for me, easily the best comic strip of all time.

Nothing I could say is going to add to or detract from Peanuts status as one of the classic comic strips, but still I'll go on record as saying it deserves that status. It really is great!This is the third volume in the series that I've read, having already gone through the 1950-52 and 53-54 books, all three obtained from my local library (which I also work at). The first two looked pretty beat up but this one was in great shape - is that evidence as to how many people started to read the whole series from the beginning but bogged down after two volumes? If so they quit too soon, things really start getting good in the third volume.The material in the first two volumes was almost all totally new to me, and the earliest strips really had sort of a different feel from the later Peanuts strips I was familiar with - both the drawing style and the humor reminded me a bit of Jules Feiffer. They were definitely great, but with the third volume Snoopy, Lucy and Linus all become much larger players in the strip, adding a lot to the off kilter humor of the strip.One thing I'll say about Schulz, even in his earliest days he was unashamed about using the same basic jokes over and over - not that any of my friends will think I have the moral authority to point the finger about that, I've been known to recycle my material too.

The master hits his stride and even though characters, plot lines, and draftsmanship are all still evolving, this volume has laugh out loud moments and flashes of insight and wisdom. Snoopy does imitations of Violet, Lucy, and others. He melts to Chopin. Dances to his own drummer. Yet he still enjoys puppy pleasures, like stealing Linus’s blanket and mad-dashing through the croquet wickets. He also engages in wishful thinking fantasies of being a different animal (rhinos, snakes, etc.) Charlie Brown fights his losing battle with self-esteem, argues the merits of Davy Crockett over Beethoven with Schroeder, has his stomach turned as he listens to Lucy instructing Linus on matters of nature and the world at large, and encounters his first frustrations with kites and trees. Pigpen emerges in full dustcloud glory. Lucy is not just a champion fuss-budget, mentor, and interpreter of the bug-world, but the character who dominates the others (not including Schroeder). Linus remains precocious in many ways, out-doing Charlie Brown in skills large and small. He also asks the shielding rhetorical question, What difference will it make in 500 years? Well, we’re one-tenth of the way there and I’m betting on all the difference as the correct answer.

I have read the first two volumes, which I need to add at some point. I am mostly borrowing them from the public library, but this is a set I would not mind having. For this third volume, I have to agree with other readers in that Schultz is finding his stride. Only thing that kind of gets me is how the girls can be so mean to Charlie Brown. Snoopy's impressions are just a hoot. And Pig-Pen is becoming a regular "dirt" philosopher. Great strip. I finished it, and I have to say that I enjoyed it very much. I will be looking forward to the other volumes. I borrowed this one from the Tyler Public Library, my local library now. * * * *Hmm, looking over my blog, it turns out I read this earlier in 2005 as well. Here is the note anyways. At any rate, rereading books like these is definitely a pleasure.http://gypsylibrarian.blogspot.com/20...

Fantagraphics did a great job putting together these complete editions of the Peanuts comic strips and I'm always happy to find them at the library when they turn up. Schulz helped turn the four panel strip - 3 for the set up, one for the punchline - into the standard for nearly all newspaper comics to come, and in these early volumes you can see him quickly developing a real mastery of the form. Part of Schulz' genius lies in realizing how much you can get away with saying when it comes from the mouths of cute children, making him a spiritual forefather to South Park, Boondocks, Home Movies... all the best stuff put out these days. Peanuts delicately balances cynicism and frustration on the one hand with joy and playfulness on the other. It's a great work of art, and you don't have to care about that fact at all in order to enjoy reading it!

Some of the beginnings of the iconic behavior we love about these characters is beginning to show up as this strip moves into its fifth and sixth years. Linus is seem more with his blanket, he is also see on the back of his mothers bike,much like Rerun was much later in the strip. Lucy is beginning to be much more aggressive, the big sister in control of everyone. Charlie Brown is still more of a prankster at this point,not the "loser" that we see much more of now. Snoopy has become a bit more eccentric,playing the vulture on occasion, and dancing when the opportunity arises. All the characters seem to show more adult traits, becoming the philosophical adults trapped in childrens bodies, that we know so well today.Again this series of books is amazing for those of us who are fans of the strips, more of a point of interest for others.

"I've got to admit it's getting better, a little better all the time..." "Tenavien" viidennen ja kuudennen vuoden aikana uusia kasvoja ei esitellä, vaan vakiintuneet hahmot kasvavat: Jaska Jokusen itsetunto on koetuksella mm. leijanlennätyksen saralla, Ressun persoonallisuus voimistuu, Eppu osoittaa olevansa riippuvainen rievustaan, Tellu rakastaa vain Amadeusta joka rakastaa vain Beethovenia...Schulzin rakastettu sarjakuva alkaa siis löytää "The Complete Peanuts 1955 to 1956" -kokoelmassa (Fantagraphics, 2005) hitaasti mutta varmasti löytää ne elementtinsä, jotka teki siitä kaikkien aikojen upeimman sarjakuvan. Kulunut ajanjakso tosin näkyy muutamien strippien aiheissa: Davy Crockett -villityksestä revitään irti runsaasti huumoria ja Elvis Presleykin mainitaan.

I love Peanuts. This early volume exemplifies the darker side with Charlie Brown's miseries and Linus' refrain that "in 500 years who will know the difference?" while also providing plenty of laugh out loud moments ("These are my feet!" "I don't know any magic."). The focus is on Charlie Brown, Lucy, Linus, Schroeder, and Snoopy. It's astonishing how well established all of them are this early considering how long they last in the strip.I do find Snoopy not nearly as entertaining in these early strips as he becomes later. And several prominent characters are not yet introduced (Woodstock, Peppermint Patty), which wouldn't be a problem but it makes some of the cast (e.g. Violet) feel less important since I know they'll eventually disappear.

Peanuts really starts to develop at this stage - you can see the very early part of Snoopy becoming the character he eventually does. The rest of the gang are starting to build their distinguishing traits: Lucy, Linus, Shroeder. The next volume looks to be interesting. I'm wondering when I will start to have the ah-ha! Moments of recognition from the Scholastic books? This far, it all seems unfamiliar - but very cool. Only about 44 years more of strips to read!

I prefer Peanuts when Snoopy had more of a personality and an inner life. And this was one entire year of Charlie Brown LOATHING himself! Real existential, Ivan Brunetti style loathing. It's a bit of a bummer!Still, I intend on reading every damn Peanuts strip ever created. Schulz was the Dickens of our time, but with fewer words, and awesome little kids that pondered the meaning of falling leaves.

Increible encontrarse con la vieja pandilla , como era originalmente. Snoopy camina en cuatro patas y resulta, para mi gusto, más gracioso siendo un perro casi normal, aunque no deja de imitar toda suerte de animales. Aunque no contiene los mejores cartones de la historia de Peanuts, empieza a entrar en esa época. La estrella de este tomo es , sin duda, Snoopy, que empieza a dejar de ser un personaje secundario para convertirse en el sello distintivo.

I suppose I discovered the "extra depths" of Charles Schulz comic strips in the late 60s. Since then I've read them often oh so often. These are the basic first beginnings of the strip...This isn't the only comic with depths of wisdom hidden in the humor, but it may be the best.I added the same to the 2 books that went before this...I mean what more can you say about Peanuts. Schulz loss was a great one and these will be just as good for years to come.

1955: Hore hore... Linus akhirnya bisa berdiri, berjalan dan berbicara! Meskipun begitu, 500 tahun dari sekarang apalah bedanya... :). Trus Snoopy suka berpura-pura jadi binatang lain. Dia juga hobi menirukan anak-anak.1956: Tetap tidak ada karakter baru. Oh ya, Snoopy ketahuan mengidap 'weed claustrophobia'. Lucy masih bikin Charlie Brown mual-mual tiap kali Lucy menerangkan sesuatu ke Linus.

It really does come together here, and you're not seeing the "learning curve" that was so obvious in the first books. At this point, there's no more "beginning"--it is a great strip.One quibble: Lucy's determination to get married, and her disappointment that her kindergarten doesn't offer classes in homemaking. Eeeeech.

Although there is still some development to go and lots of characters still to introduce, the strip by this time is getting really good, is much more mature and is totally unique. No new characters at all are introduced in this volume, but Linus starts talking, Snoopy starts dancing and Charlie Brown is Charlie Brown.

In this volume you get to see the characters start to evolve into the people we knew during the tv years of Peanuts. From Linus' deeper dependence on his blanket, to Snoopy's imagination, you see the great wisdom that Charles Schulz had in helping us understand our own world. A great classic for everyone to enjoy!

Por alguna extraña razón, que probablemente tenga que ver con el merchandising derivado de Peanuts, creía que las aventuras de Charlie Brown y compañía eran otra cosa, más alegre, más naif, más optimista.Pero leo esto y me encuentro con angustia vital, cinismo, mala leche...No es que no me haya gustado sino que ¡Me ha roto los esquemas!

The jokes and characters really feel like Peanuts. Lucy is obnoxious and Charlie Brown is full of self loathing. Schroeder and Pig Pen are pretty much themselves now. Many of the long-running gags are in place too. The jokes sometimes get repetitive when you read a lot at once, but they're still funny.

it was funny. i like charlie brown because everyone thinks he is not smart but sometimes he actually is. i want to read the entire collection. i find thst lucy is funny because she says to linus to put his arms up.

I enjoyed another volume of Peanuts comics. This volume had many different ideas of how modern inventions have come into society like air conditioners. Also Snoopy's many impressions were great. Linus started having personal conversations with Charlie Brown.

This isn't even mine! It is Andrew's and it is in a box somewhere! *Finally recovered it from the box and finished. Not as charming as the first volume, but still hell of charming. I love Lucy. I feel like I can identify with her a lot.

description: The third volume in our acclaimed series takes us into the mid-1950s as Linus learns to talk, Snoopy begins to explore his eccentricities (including his hilarious first series of impressions), Lucy's unrequited crush on Schroeder takes final shape, and Charlie Brown becomes...well, even more Charlie Brown-ish! Over half of the strips in this volume have never been printed since their original appearance in newspapers a half-century ago! Even the most dedicated Peanuts collector/fan is sure to find many new treasures. The Complete Peanuts will run 25 volumes, collecting two years chronologically at a rate of two a year for twelve years. Each volume is designed by the award-winning cartoonist Seth (It's a Good Life If You Don't Weaken) and features impeccable production values; every single strip from Charles M. Schulz's 50-year American classic is reproduced better than ever before. This volume includes an introduction by Matt Groening (The Simpsons) as well as the popular Complete Peanuts index, a hit with librarians and collectors alike, and an epilogue by series editor Gary Groth. 2005 Eisner Award winner, Best Archival Collection/Project.
title:
The Complete Peanuts, Vol. 3: 1955-1956
      
          (The Complete Peanuts #3)
